data.text:
Abhik Hazra, Student, Lovely School of Architecture and Design, Lovely Professional University, Punjab, India.

INTRODUCTION:

The Victoria Memorial Hall was built in Kolkata, then the capital of British India, to commemorate Queen Victoria. The project was conceived by Lord Curzon, Viceroy of India from 1899 to 1905, who wanted it to be established as a historical museum to commemorate the Queen. with a special focus on Indo-British history. Built on 57 hectares of land and designed by Sir William Emerson (then President of the Royal Institute of British Architecture), the grandeur of the monument is evident in its architecture, which is predominantly Italian Renaissance in character. mixed with nuances of orientalism. Widely hailed as the finest example of Indo-British architecture in India and often referred to as the “Taj of the Raj”, Victoria Memorial Hall was laid by the Prince of Wales in January 1906 and officially opened to the public in 1921. It was declared an institution of national importance by the Government of India Act 1935.Today, the Victoria Memorial Hall is considered one of the best examples of a unique paradigious of fine arts, in which four different artificial fields, architecture, sculpture, painting and gardening come together.

HISTORY:

One of the landmarks of Kolkata, Victoria Memorial is a great British structure that was completely built of white marble. The Royal Gallery contains paintings of the Queen and Prince Albert, as well as artwork depicting events in the Queen’s life. Here you will find weapons, sculptures, maps, coins, stamps and textiles. A 16-foot-tall bronze statue of the Victory Angel stands atop the large edifice in the central dome. It is ball-bearing and rotates. with the wind. The British Indian states and people seeking favours from the British contributed around INR 10 million to the construction of this majestic building which took more than 20 years to complete. The main building is set in over 150 acres of landscaped gardens. A gallery of national leaders with paintings of India’s freedom fighters was added to the post-independence Victoria Memorial of India along with various relics. The Victoria Memorial stands on the Maidan (grounds) on the banks of the Hooghly River. Nearby is the well-known Chowringhee Road or Jawaharlal Nehru Road. The Memorial Victoria is maintained by the Ministry of Culture.

LOCATION:

The monument is located on the Maidan (ground) on the banks of the Hooghly River, near Jawaharlal Nehru Street. Lord Curzon conceived it. It is currently the finest and most famous art building and museum in Kolkata, India under the Ministry of Culture. Indian government. Construction of the Victoria Memorial was delayed by Curzon’s departure from India in 1905, resulting in a loss of local enthusiasm for the project and the need to test the foundations. The cornerstone of the Victoria Memorial was laid in 1906 and the building opened in 1921.Martin and Co. from Calcutta. Work on the superstructure began in 1910.

ARCHITECTURE STYLE:

The prominent one is the IndoSaracenic style displaying the elements of both British and Mughal architecture. Also, the monument hints at some Egyptian, Deccani, Venetian, and Islamic architectural elements. The palace is made out of Makrana marble that gives a royal vibe altogether.

The architect of the Victoria Memorial was William Emerson (1843–1924).The design is in an Indo-Aracene Revival style using a mixture of British and Mughal elements with architectural influences from Venice, Egypt and Deccani. The building measures 103 x 69 m (338 x 228 ft) and reaches a height of 56 m (184 ft). It is built of white Makrana marble.

The Victoria Memorial Gardens were designed by Lord Redesdale and David Prain. Emerson’s assistant Vincent Jerome Esch designed the north side bridge and garden gates. In 1902, Emerson commissioned Esch to sketch his original design for the Victoria Monument.

On the central dome of the Victoria Memorial is the 4.9 m high figure of the Victory Angel. Around the dome are allegorical sculptures including Art, Architecture, Justice and Charity, and above the north porch Motherhood, Prudence and Learning.The Victory Monument is made of white Makrana marble.In design it is reminiscent of the Taj Mahal with its dome, four branches, octagonal domed chattris, high portals, terrace and domed corner towers.Talking about the design, Victoria Memorial is inspired by the majestic Taj Mahal.The design elements incorporated in the architecture are one central dome, four other domes, a terrace, chhatris shaped like octagonal domes, and high portals.On top of the central dome, there is a statue of the Angel of Victory which is 16 feet high.Many allegorical sculptures can also be noted, for example, the northern porch shows learning, maternity and caution.

Similar to the Taj Mahal, the Victoria Memorial is made of Makrana marble brought from Rajasthan. Aside from the dome, several other architectural elements also resemble the Taj. You can surely call it one of the best. Examples of the fusion of Mughal and British architecture. This architectural style was used by the British in the 19th century and was known as the Indo-Saracenic Revival architectural style. In the central dome you will find many allegorical writings representing charity, motherhood, prudence and wisdom. There is also a Victoria Memorial Museum inside the memorial which contains colonial era paintings and Victorian memorabilia.In addition, the Victoria Memorial Museum also has some postal and manuscript seals returning to the Mughal era. As many as 25 galleries are gift withinside the memorial to delight the eyes of the visitors. Some of the galleries are the Central Hall, gallery of photographs, Calcutta gallery, gallery of palms and arsenal, and the gallery of sculptures. And withinside the National Leaders Gallery, you could additionally locate the photographs of Indian freedom combatants being displayed. Indians funded the development of the memorial-For building this captivating memorial, donations have been widely wide-spread from all throughout India and therefore a huge part of the development become funded through the Indians. The British Government did fund the development however partly. There is a statue of the Angel of Victory that is sixteen toes in top and positioned on pinnacle of the terrific dome which rotates with the float of wind.

FEAUTURES:

Ceiling and Ceiling treatment: The monument has geometrical ceiling patterns with creative cornices designs. They were all white in color. Distemper paint was used over the ceiling. The designs on the ceilings were matching with the room size and shape having square and rectangular patterns.

Wall and Wall treatment: Walls of the monuments were painted in white and off white color.The walls were having smooth finish.Inside the dome the side area on the wall had stones fixed on them.The stone were Makrana marble fixed like brick design on the walls.Stones were in white color, smooth in finish, and rectangular in shape.The stone wall was deeply engraved with the text of Queen Victoria’s Imperial Declaration speech. The doors and windows were made of wood and some of them were framed with glass. The doors and windows were dark brown.

Furniture: Furniture for the monument included lockers, an open shelf, tables, chairs and a side table. Some furniture was made from mahogany wood with polish applied. They had a smooth, dark brown finish. They were heavy, strong and sturdy. Some furniture was oak.

Lighting: No specific colonial lighting fixtures were found in the monument. Modern lights such as fluorescent tubes and incandescent bulbs have been used in the monuments. Projectors have been installed above the paintings displayed on the walls of the central hall of the monument.

Accessories: All the add-ons have been unique from every other. The monument displayed many add-ons which specifically covered pics and statues. The statues have been lifestyles sized. All statues have been white in colour reflecting the craftsmanship of the sculptor. The pics have been of all sizes with golden frames. The pics have been in colour and in black and white too. The frames have been directly in addition to decorative in layout and have been pretty heavy in weight.

The Galleries A large number of artefact’s from the invaluable collections of the Memorial are on display. They are suitably placed in various galleries. The galleries include :

The Royal Gallery

Entrance Hall Portrait Gallery

The Queen’s Hall

The Prince Hall

National Leaders’ Gallery

Indian Schools of Art

Calcutta Gallery

Durbar Hall

GARDEN:

In addition to the valuable collection in the galleries, the memorial has a picturesque and well-tended garden with water bodies, lawns, gravel paths, historic busts and statues, and a rich collection of around 2,378 trees. The original garden design for the Victoria Memorial was made in 1915 in consultation with Lord Redesdale (recognized as the leading amateur authority on landscape gardening), Mr. E. White of Messrs. Milner and Co., landscapers and architects, and Sir David Prain, Superintendent, Botanical Gardens, Calcutta and Director of the Botanical Survey of India. Currently, the garden is an important tourist attraction itself and attracts almost 3.5 million visitors each year.

CONCLUSION:

Today, the Victoria Memorial stands in ethereal splendor over the wide expanse of Calcutta’s Maidan, surrounded by an elegant garden with an angle of black bronze, as a grand “Italian Renaissance” style white marble edifice with the essence of the Mughal touch. with a cornet in his hand on top of the dome of the monument and is one of the most renowned place in and around India and World.So,it should be on your travelling list if you are visiting Kolkata.
